title: NEW HEAD COACH APPOINTED: Old Town Shamrocks Rugby appoints Thierry Demoulin
content:
Old Town Shamrocks Rugby has appointed France-born and long-time Finland resident Thierry Demoulin as the new head coach of the menâ€™s first team. Demoulin steps in after Marko Sallert, who led the team for two seasons together with assistant coach Linus Backman.

Under Sallertâ€™s leadership, Shamrocks reached the Finnish Championship Final for the first time in club history in 2024, and he was also named Coach of the Year in Finland. In the 2025 season, the club narrowly missed the playoffs.

Extensive experience in Finnish and international rugby

Demoulin brings a wealth of experience as a player, coach and referee. He began playing rugby at age seven in France, was selected to the French youth national programme, and represented Racing Club France. His playing career included time in Franceâ€™s 1st Division B and 2nd Division, also at semi-professional level.

As a coach, Demoulin has led U16 juniors in Nantes, coached a Helsinki club from 1999â€“2006 (winning two Finnish Championships), and served as Head Coach of the Finland menâ€™s national team from 2001â€“2005. He has also worked across Finland as a development officer, coached the Finland womenâ€™s academy (2008â€“2011), and served as backs coach for the Finland womenâ€™s national team (2019â€“2022). In recent years, he has worked as a referee before returning to coaching.

â€œRugby is like chess â€“ everything is built before the scoreâ€

Demoulin describes his coaching philosophy as strategic and focused on developing playersâ€™ understanding and skills.

â€“ â€œI see rugby as a chess game. You must construct the play according to the opponent to be able to score. Everything that happens before the scoring moment matters,â€ says Demoulin.

He emphasises technical development, open communication, and leadership from experienced players. He views the teamâ€™s goals on a 1â€“3 year timeline.

â€“ â€œI want to win as soon as possible, but building the structure of the team comes first. Players should not carry unnecessary pressure about winning everything,â€ he adds.

Beginnersâ€™ course continues â€“ pre-season preparations begin soon

Shamrocksâ€™ free beginnersâ€™ course on Thursdays from 20:30 to 22:00 continues for two more sessions: 11 December and 18 December.
New participants are welcome to join at any time.

The official pre-season begins in January 2026, giving the team five months of preparation before the Finnish Championship season kicks off.

More information: www.shamrocks.fi

title: Shamrocks Begin Title Hunt with a Dominant 43â€“0 Victory â€“ Kalev Awaits in Round Two
content:
PORVOO â€“ MAY 2025

The 2025 Finnish Rugby Championship kicked off in style for Old Town Shamrocks, who delivered a statement win in front of a home crowd in Hammars, defeating Turku Eagles 43â€“0. While the scoreboard showed clear dominance, the mood in the team was focused and determined.

â€œWe werenâ€™t clinical enough,â€ said team captain Samu-Petteri PÃ¤Ã¤kkÃ¶. â€œIf we had finished our chances better, this couldâ€™ve been a triple-digit game. We know thereâ€™s still plenty to improve.â€
The game featured standout performances from several players. Jay Robertson, returning from a long injury break, impressed both in attack and defense. Ari Gali Valls controlled the tempo with precision kicking, and the forwards dominated physically from start to finish.

A Season with One Clear Goal: Redemption

This season is about more than good rugby â€“ itâ€™s about unfinished business. Shamrocks came heartbreakingly close to their first-ever Finnish championship last year, losing the final to Helsinki Warriors 15â€“13, just two points shy of glory.

â€œThat loss still stings,â€ admitted head coach Marko Sallert. â€œBut it also gave us a clear path forward. The way the team responded this offseason was phenomenal â€“ the best training attendance weâ€™ve ever had.â€
â€œWeâ€™re no longer just a team of players â€“ weâ€™re a unit with structure, discipline, and hunger,â€ added assistant coach Linus Backman.

The 2025 menâ€™s championship features six teams:
Old Town Shamrocks (Porvoo), 
Helsinki Warriors, 
Helsinki Rugby Club (HRC), 
Turku Eagles, 
Tampere Rugby Club (TRC), 
Tallinn Kalev

Every team plays each other home and away. Itâ€™s a tight race where every match counts.

Porvoo Is Backing Its Team

The fanbase in Porvoo has grown steadily â€“ especially after last yearâ€™s home semifinal drew record attendance. Shamrocks have worked hard to turn match days into full experiences.

â€œItâ€™s no longer just about the rugby,â€ said club chairman Stefan Rogers. â€œPeople come for the food, the community â€“ and then they stay for the sport. Thatâ€™s how we build something lasting.â€

Next Challenge: Kalev from Tallinn

The next fixture will be a true test: Tallinn Kalev, known for its tight, national-team-level cohesion, will visit Hammars on Sunday, June 16 at 13:00.

â€œTheyâ€™re a disciplined, physical side. But weâ€™re playing at home, and weâ€™ll make sure they feel it,â€ said captain PÃ¤Ã¤kkÃ¶. â€œWeâ€™ve set the tone â€“ now itâ€™s about raising the bar.â€
Shamrocks will play three consecutive home games to start the season before heading into Julyâ€™s away stretch with matches in Turku, Tallinn, Vantaa, Tampere, and Helsinki.

English:

Shamrocks is doing exceptionally well and is competing for the Finnish Rugby Championship gold this year.

Old Town Shamrocks traveled to Tampere over the weekend to play a crucial match in the Finnish Rugby Championship. Tampere Rugby Club started the game strong, but OTS once again demonstrated resilience and determination. Shamrocks turned the game in their favor in the second half and ultimately secured a 32-7 victory. The try scorers in the Tampere game were Jay Robertson and Widz Rahui, who both scored twice. Additionally, Vice-Captain Samu PÃ¤Ã¤kkÃ¶ and Captain Akseli Peltoniemi also found the try zone. Alexander Bannatyne successfully converted one extra point.

Old Town Shamrocks (OTS) has had a strong season and currently sits in second place on the table with only three games remaining. The season has been marked by determination, hard-fought victories, and a few challenges, but Shamrocks has proven to be a formidable force. The team has accumulated 24 points, with Warriors Rugby Club being the only team to have defeated Shamrocks. Consistent performance has put Shamrocks in an excellent position as the season heads towards its conclusion. The next three matches will be crucial for the playoffs. First, OTS will travel to Tallinn to face Kalev, followed by an away game against Turku. The season will conclude with a home match against Kalev. Securing second place in the standings is of utmost importance for OTS, as it would guarantee a home semi-final against the team finishing third. Shamrocks understands the significance of home-field advantage, especially in a high-stakes semi-final, and the team is determined to claim that spot. Meanwhile, the league winner advances directly to the final.

The success of this season is attributed to coaches Marko Sallert and Linus Backman, who have managed to instill a unified and, above all, disciplined style of play in the team. Under their leadership, Shamrocks has developed throughout the season, maintaining focus and performance even in tough situations.

This yearâ€™s finals day will be held in Espoo and is fast approaching. Shamrocks is firmly focused on maintaining consistent performance, as it is key to a strong finish to the season. To secure a home semi-final, every match counts, and the team is preparing to give its all in the upcoming challenges. The season is nearing its end, and OTS fans have plenty of reasons to be excited. The team is in a strong position, and with a few solid performances, Shamrocks could be playing a home semi-final and contending for the championship. The road ahead is challenging, but Shamrocks has already shown that it has the determination and discipline needed to overcome any obstacle. All eyes are now on the upcoming matches as OTS continues its journey towards the championship.

The team will travel to Tallinn on Saturday to play against Kalev. Even a single point from that match would secure a place in the semi-finals on September 21st. The Finnish Championship finals will be played on September 28th in LeppÃ¤vaara, Espoo. In addition to the playoffs and the womenâ€™s and menâ€™s Finnish Championship finals, Shamrocksâ€™ U8 and U13 juniors will also be playing on finals day.
